Fields.DialogueText: Hmm...
What's that matter, Hiei?
I just saw what I think was a ningyo over on the starboard side.
Ningyo? Isn't that a Japanese mermaid?
A rather rough comparison, but yes. I was just trying to ascertain whether its presence is a good omen, or bodes ill for our success.
Exactly what did you see?
I told you... a ningyo. Only the fin, of course, but you never see them up close that often.
In that case, how can you be sure that it was a ningyo, and not something else? It was probably just a fish splashing about, as usual.
Tell me, Kanchou. Let's leave aside if I have ever seen a ningyo before. But have you seen one? Or any mermaid, for that matter?
Well, no. What's your point?
My point is that, given that you have no point of reference, do you really have a right to dictate what is not a mermaid?

Fields.MenuText: When you explain it like that, no?
Is this some sort of riddle?
By that same logic, I don't think you have the right to say that something is a mermaid.

Fields.DialogueText: You see? You are taking a step toward enlightenment.
You're right on the mark. My reasoning is based off a koan about a dragon's scale.
You are missing the point, Kanchou. It's about faith.
Could you explain things a little more clearly, please?
What? And take the mystery out of it?
Hiei...
All right. The point I'm making is that things exist beyond our limited understanding. By recognizing that we can't see everything, we can start to grasp those intangible things.
I see. Say, do you think it's true that their flesh makes you immortal?
Who knows? I'm not interested in finding out. If I stayed unchanged for too long, I would never find the Pure Land.
Still, I wonder if the Morganas perhaps partook of that delicacy? They certainly keep coming back, again and again!
@BATTLE
Thanks, I guess? Still confused...
What are you fiddling with there?
A replica of a magatama.
Interesting. Is it a symbol of your mountain?
Not really, but artifacts of this sort have popped up all across Japan.
What do they symbolize?
Nobody really knows. Those who do are long gone.
Any theories?
Some think that the gods made the first ones, but even they can't agree on exactly why. Maybe they just wanted gaudy jewelry. They had not been taught the way of the Buddha yet.
That's neat. But that's not quite what I meant. What do you think they mean?
Me? I'll tell you, if you tell me your interpretation first. Share and share alike, after all.

Fields.MenuText: A dew droplet.
Blood.
Some sort of tooth.

Fields.DialogueText: That's kind of like my own idea. Not quite, but pretty close.
A rather morbid concept, but a reasonable one. Certainly some warlords used it as a symbol of their might.
That's actually a popular theory among scholars. I wonder what a Funayūrei's tooth is like?
Okay, I told you my theory. So, what's yours?
I believe that the magatama is a tear.
A teardrop?
Right. It represents the melancholy hope of a long-forgotten people, the idea that we can rebuild from sorrow.
That's a pretty interesting perspective on it.
Arigatō. But yours was fascinating as well.
Like you said, there are a lot of ways to look at things – thought it's tough for me to look at the Morganas in a good light.
@BATTLE
I just thought that you might be attracted to it if it embodies the waters.
I wouldn't want to find out.
Whew! It's getting pretty hot out here.
Maybe this will help.
Thanks. Say, that's a neat little fan you've got there, Hiei. Well, not so little, but neat. Where did you get it?
I received one as a gift when I was stationed at the Marshall Islands.
That explains why you have it. You're not one to really collect "frivolous" things.
It is a little gaudy, isn't it? I think this is more of a touristy one than a genuine craftwork.
Then why haven't you gotten rid of it?
It was a gift to me, so I cannot simply reject it. Plus, it is irresponsible to waste things. And... I liked my time there.
Interesting culture?
I would say so. They have such skill in navigating by the celestial bodies, and they strongly believe in the virtue of hospitality.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think they're doing okay now?
How is Japan getting along with them?
It's always interesting to experience new cultures.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know. The war is leaving much devastation everywhere.
Not the best. There are efforts to bring them into Japan's fold, but they are resisting.
It is, isn't it? I'm sad that I am away from my home country and mountain, but in a way, this is helping me grow stronger.
Well, you may as well put away the fan now, Hiei. A cold wind is picking up.
In that case, I'm hanging onto it for good luck. A cold wind spells trouble on the horizon.
Sometimes you're just too superstitious...
*ALARM*
And sometimes you're right.
@BATTLE
Let's do what we can to keep the collateral damage down, then.
I feel the same way.
That makes sense. They want to preserve the values they already have.
Hiei? Hiei!
I'm fine. Just grazed my shoulder a little.
Are you going to be okay?
Don't worry. It's a price I pay for being at the forefront in battles. Those Funayūrei may be brutes, but they have an edge of cunning beneath it all.
If they are going to single out targets, I'd rather it be me than someone more vulnerable. Trust me, I make my enemies regret choosing me as an opponent.
You sure you're okay? You're staggering a bit, you know?
A true swordsman can fight in any stance, even when falling into the grave.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we can still give you support.
At least put on a little more armor.
I'll put my faith in you. You have more to teach me after this.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate that. Just be careful not to get caught in the brawl.
I can't. At this point it would slow me down to get hit more.
That's the spirit, Kanchou. Don't worry, I'm almost done here.
I have to say, Hiei, you really are something.
It's nothing. Or rather, it's something that is in all of us. I can feel it in you, growing every day. And across the fleet, it's resonating.
What is it? Determination? Courage?
That, and a love for the world.
The last seems kind of odd on the battlefield.
Such is the paradox of soldiers. Come, let us finish this.
@BATTLE
That's a nice photo you have there.
Careful! This is the centerpiece of my shrine to the Imperial Family. I pray that they, and their ancestors, will watch over our mission.
Got it. Is this the Emperor?
Oh, no! This is one of the princes – Nobuhito, also called Takamatsu.
You know him?
He served onboard me for a little while some years ago as a sailor.
Huh. I didn't know that the royal family did such stuff.
The imperial line is steeped in warriors and soldiers, so it is only natural to keep the tradition going. Takamatsu in particular excelled out here.
Well, no wonder, with you as a teacher.
Oh, hush. I learned much more from him. I will never forget the honor he gave all of us.
So is he taking part in this war, too?
Of course! This struggle is a national effort, and not even the smallest kami, or meanest yokai, or humblest farmer is separated from it.

Fields.MenuText: What's his opinion on the war?
Maybe you should write to him sometime.
You really admire your leaders, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: He is whole-heartedly supporting the campaigns against the Funayūrei. He's more critical of our land expansions, though.
What? No, he would not want to dally with a common soldier.
Of course, they are the pillars of our proud islands. Though mortal, they possess both spiritual and physical strength to move us forward.
*ALARM*
Looks like we have company. Time to do honor to your prince. What do you say?
My fight is for all of our honors. May the kami and Buddhas guide me to victory. For the Chrysanthemum Throne!
For the world!
@BATTLE
I see. So there are even divisions at the highest ranks in this conflict...
Hence the shrine.
Yes. Though to be honest, I really did it because I thought they would like it if they were to ever visit again.
Are you sure? I think this would be good for the both of you.
Yes, you're right. He's the kind of person I could relate to.
That's enough training for you for now, Kanchou.
Good, I'm bushed – and famished!
Well, I can help with the latter at least. Dig in!
Thanks, Hiei! Don't mind if I do!
Oh, I almost forgot. You might want a little water with that...
Yeow! My tongue's on fire.
The curry can be a little strong for the unprepared, can't it?
It certainly is. Couldn't you have made it a little milder?
Yes, but I like maintaining the tradition of Yokosuka.
The naval foundry where you were born? I take it they like their curry, then.
It's only natural, as port cities are hubs for trade. There are even special packets that were distributed among the naval forces there.
That's really interesting.
You know, I have thought of making my own. I'm not sure, though. It seems somewhat frivolous in a way.

Fields.MenuText: Everything connects to the Buddha, as you say, so surely you can find a way for this to work.
Just look at it as a way to keep your senses active.
Like I said, you deserve a few small rewards for yourself now and then.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a good point. After all, the Buddha first began teaching in India, where originated curry itself.
I see what you mean. When your mouth is on fire, it helps you stay alert and aware of potential dangers. Plus, it helps strengthen my resistance to heat.
I see such things as temptations to lure me off the path. On the other hand, experiencing them may give me new insights on my journey.
Thanks for the water.
You are welcome. Are you all right now?
Yep. Actually, mind if I have a little more, please? I think I'm getting accustomed to it.
Of course. Have as much as you want. I am planning to share the rest with the crew as a whole.
*ALARM*
We can have the food to celebrate after the next battle. Because it looks like things are really going to heat up now.
@BATTLE
See? I knew you'd figure things out.
Just try not to go overboard, okay?
Besides, I think you've earned something, for being my friend and teacher at the very least.
Arigatō, Kanchou.
Okay, let's try this. Hiya... wah!
Aaa! Watch it, you almost killed me!
Sorry, Kanchou. On the positive side, your reflexes are certainly improving.
Thanks, I guess. But what was with the wild swings? And... Why do you seem to have two more arms than usual?
A Nagano no Kami made a contraption to let me wield extra arms in combat.
I see. Belles certainly have a lot of different talents.
As to be expected of all living things.
And I can see how such an invention could come in handy for you, given how you have so many weapons.
I know. On the other hand, the contraption is not entirely perfect.
I could tell.
I am very grateful for my friend's gift, but I feel bad that I cannot get this to work properly.

Fields.MenuText: I know you have adjusted to various upgrades over the years, so give it some time.
You'll just have to work around the handicap and make a new style of fighting.
Maybe you should study the mechanics a little to understand it a little better.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right, and each one has left me more able to carry on my missions for Japan. I'm sure I can make this work.
Good point. I need to be prepared to fight in any condition or position, so this is simply another approach to hone.
Perhaps. My true skill is on the battlefield, so I really think that those skills are better suited for others. Still, I could pick up a thing or two.
In any case, it's good to see that you are getting along with people outside of battles.
Well, this is to support me in battle, but I see what you mean. My skills are primarily oriented toward combat, so I have found that teammates can cover my flaws, and mine theirs.
Want to give it another go?
I believe I will. I think I have an idea on how to maneuver with this gear.
*ALARM*
I hope so, because we're going to need every weapon we can to get out of this squeeze.
@BATTLE
Rest easy, disturbed kami. I know not why you fight, but I will fight on as long as you threaten us.
@BATTLE
Good job, Hiei. You're an excellent soldier.
You compliment me too much, Kanchou. I am but a simple monk.
But for a monk, you surprisingly know a lot about warfare.
That is actually not that surprising if you know your history. During the warring period, there were a number of warrior monks, said to be as dangerous as a samurai.
Huh, that's pretty interesting. Are there any on your mountain?
There were, but they were wiped out in Nobunaga's campaigns.
I'm sorry.
Don't be. It was the price they paid for placing earthly ambitions over spiritual ones.
Is that why you try to avoid "temptations"?
Indeed, I want to serve my nation and my faith with all of my ability. I will not allow my honor to be stained with petty greed, hate, or lust.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps you can be the founder of a new cadre of warrior monks, then.
Still, the earth is beautiful in its own way.
Do not let yourself be chained too much to the past.

Fields.DialogueText: Again, you are exalting me too highly. Although, it would be nice to teach others to follow the tradition.
It is, isn't it? Seeking spiritual wisdom yet grounded to the imperfection of life... It is no wonder that I was born a kami.
I know the past, present, and future are all intertwined. I cannot allow myself to become stuck on one spoke or another, if I want the wheel to keep spinning.
Now, then, I am going to meditate on what is to come.
Mind if I join you?
Be my guest. You have the spark of a warrior monk in you as well, you know.
Greetings, Kanchou.
Hello, Hiei. Uh, why exactly are you standing right at the bow of the ship?
Meditating.
I could see that. I meant, why here, of all places?
I am trying to feel the internal air around me.
Internal air? Excuse me for my ignorance, but with air, I don't really see an inside or out.
I know, but I want to solve that mystery and progress with my training.
Oh, so this is for some sort of special technique.
In Tibet, they call it "Lung-gom-pa," a supernatural run where you may move at extraordinary speeds for days on end. A similar practice was undertaken at my mountain.
That sounds kind of tricky.
It is. But I must overcome this limit if I wish to make a difference against the Funayūrei.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe study of Buddhist teachings in Tibet could help you better understand how it's done.
I'm not sure if they intended the method for ships.
Perhaps they meant the air you breathe in.

Fields.DialogueText: I have started to read some of their texts. Still, that nation is rather materialistic in some respects. Such pride comes before a fall.
This is a spiritual technique, one that comes from the soul. And the Buddha welcomes all souls, whether a snail, or a human, or a mountain.
Thank you. I was thinking that might be the way to approach the matter.
Well, I'll leave you to that. I need to check on the radar again.
*ALARM*
Then again, it's a little late for that. Let's get read...
Here I come!
Whoa! You're going really fast this time, Hiei!
I have yet to polish the technique, but even this minor improvement gives me an edge against these yokai. Have at thee!
@BATTLE
Nice flag. What's it for, out of curiosity?
That is the emblem of Sasebo. I stayed there when we were keeping an eye on Korea and China during the last war.
Oh, I see. I was a little curious since it looked like a cross in the middle.
That likely reflects the hidden Christian population. One of the adjacent islands housed many of them when they went into hiding.
And how are they doing now?
The remaining descendants are doing well – the flag is actually based on a key church in the area. You have to admire their determination at the very least.
Even though you do not follow the same religion?
The ways of the Buddha are all religions. The others just have not recognized it yet.
That's... one way of looking at it.
In any case, I respect people who show conviction for their faith. Just as I will never give up on my own.

Fields.MenuText: Weren't they in hiding because of your country?
It must be hard, to stay faithful even as you die.
At least they can be open about their faith now.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a low blow, Kanchou. This is true, but we have become more open to them.
Life is full of challenges. It is only natural that the last one be the hardest. But stay strong. I am confident that each of us will find what we are looking for in the end.
True, though I think it is the thought you put into it that matters more than where you show it.
I hope that they are doing all right now.
We'll just have to believe in them, if not what they believe in.
Excellent idea. I hold faith that though we may not reconcile our different beliefs – after all, diversity is key to enlightenment – we can find common love and strength.
I hope so. We'll need that strength to hold off the Morganas.
*ALARM*
Here I come, fallen souls. May we one day understand why we fight each other.
@BATTLE
Is something wrong, Hiei? You seem a little down.
Don't worry, it's just a little extra work for me.
What happened?
Some seawater splashed onto the garden and ruined a few of the plants, so I need to regrow this section.
I warned you that something like this might happen. Not many plants can survive out at sea.
I knew that from the beginning. Even so, I have no room for tears. I must plant the new batch quickly.
But you'll run into the same problem again, you know.
Nothing lasts forever, Kanchou. Land-bound vegetation also decays over time, and sudden blows from the elements can doom them in a heartbeat. Even my country...
What about Japan?
My homeland was made by blessed deities on the waves of eternity, but the waters are also blessed. And in time, water erodes even the strongest stone.
You seem pretty calm about that, though.
Whatever comes, I will fight on. Such is the way of life. No matter what, we endure the storm and push back the darkness.

Fields.MenuText: Still, wouldn't it have been better to not plant them to begin with, and save them the grief?
Do you ever worry what will happen to you in the end?
All we can do is limit the risk, then.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps, and this is somewhat of a guilty pleasure of mine. On the other hand, this way they at least have the chance to blossom and see the world, however shortly they are permitted.
I have. But, I cannot afford to mourn. My life is one of service, and one way or another, I shall die with no regrets.
Granted that still requires trial and error. At least now I have a better idea of how to properly handle the plants.
Mind if I give you a hand with this?
That would be appreciated, thank you. I wish to apologize for all the trouble. I am really best suited for warfare.
Hey, you're learning right? You'll be a master in no time.
Never a master, but nevertheless doing the best I can.
That's all I can ask.
*ALARM*
Now, then, we may not be able to overcome the sea's natural challenges, but we can at least clear out some of the unnatural hazards.
@BATTLE
Be on guard. You never know when reinforcements may arrive.
@BATTLE
Well, I think that wraps up the battle.
Still, we made a good dent in the Morganas. And that deserves a celebration. Are you coming?
I will come, but I will probably just stick in the background. These things are not really my cup of tea.
Well, at least it's a start.
You know, Kanchou...
Yes, Hiei?
I wonder if I should have been a better friend to my past comrades?
Well, you could only do so much when you couldn't speak. You're more than making up for it now.
Still, I wonder what could have been...
Who says it's over yet?
What do you mean?
Your old cadets and other companions are probably still out there, right? So why not write them a letter?
But it would be rather rude to just write to them out of the blue, when we have not been properly introduced.

Fields.MenuText: Since they served on you, wouldn't it also be rude to fail to reach out to them?
It's the thought that counts.
Have faith in them. They'll be happy you contacted them.

Fields.DialogueText: That is also true. It would be an affront as a host to not extend hospitality.
I feel that actions speak louder than words, but your point is correct. I will do what I believe is righteous.
You're right. Comrades – and friends – trust each other, and through our bonds we learn more about the world.
Thank you for the advice. I'll get started on that promptly.
Hold your horses! We have a party to attend, remember?
Ah, yes. After you, Kanchou.
There is more to these Morganas than meets the eye, I suspect.
@BATTLE
There! We've got them good now!
Think again, Kanchou. Just look over there.
Reinforcements. How lovely.
It is not surprising, though. Yokai are tricky by nature, and should never be underestimated.
I've heard you use that term before. That's a term for monsters, right?
Supernatural ones. Though of what sort has yet to be determined.
What do you mean by that?
As with mundane species, and with kami, yokai can be split into different types. Some are mischievous and some are malevolent.
Interesting. Which one do you think the Morganas are?
Keep in mind that they are rather blurred categories. But I think the latter.
They fight us out of hate?
Partially, though I think it's more that they have been birthed from our violence. Perhaps that is why they continue to endure despite our raids...
So you think that they are a punishment, in a way?
Perhaps not to punish, but to cleanse. When mold infects a tree, you burn it so life can continue.

Fields.MenuText: There are plenty of positive aspects of humanity, though. Love, hope, dreams...
So what do we do?
They could be here for other reasons, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, and that is why we must stop them. Even if yokai reveal the darkness in the world, knowledge of the light will save us all.
We fight on. What else?
That is a valid point. Still, I think it helps explain why they seem to reflect our sins and have emerged in such a turbulent era.
In any case, don't slack off! We must stay focused on the current battle!
Right! Sorry about that, Hiei.
You are still learning. But you are getting better. Perhaps we can hunt other yokai when we have the chance.
But...
Even if it is our fate to die, why should we give up? We must stay strong as determined warriors.
Great tune, Hiei. That's an unusual flute.
Actually, this is a charumera, used by shina soba vendors.
Oh, you mean ramen. I didn't know that you liked the noodle.
I don't. It is a frivolous style of food that serves as a temptation to the unenlightened. But, the music of the small stands is rather compelling to me.
How so?
Well, it may be a simple jingle, but it has a humble feel to it. Plus, it reminds me of better times. Now that the war is on, such foods are rare.
That makes sense. They might still be making some in China.
Yes, but it lacks the Japanese flavor. I have tried some before, and it was not as good.
But they came from China.
Originally, but now they are ours.

Fields.MenuText: They are probably both good in their own way.
Everything changes over time, even food.
You're awfully defensive for a food you say is frivolous.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. Everyone has their own way to interpret things. I just like one over the other.
Good point. Actually, I wonder what the noodle will be like in the years to come?
Well, it has a fair following. And I always defend my nation's honor.
It's interesting that even food can lead to different types of music.
Such is the wonder of life, how it branches and sprouts in all directions.
Maybe we should cook up some soba sometime.
Perhaps.
*ALARM*
For now, let's work to fry some Morganas.
@BATTLE
Let's see. I drew six this time. Now for the next...
What's with the bamboo sticks? Expanding your chopstick collection?
Actually, I am attempting zeichiku. It is a Chinese style of divination.
What do you want to predict?
I think that it could offer some good insights for our next battle.
Isn't fortune telling kind of unreliable?
It is simply like studying the weather, or the growth of trees, and making rational predictions.
Those are different.
Are they? The spiritual world guides us to our destinies. We simply have to look for the right signs.

Fields.MenuText: What if the possible predictions are too limited?
I don't believe that fortunes can be predicted.
Wouldn't a Japanese style work better for you?

Fields.DialogueText: That is a possibility, I admit, but even a small glimpse into the deeper realm can be useful.
That's part of your problem. Fortunes are like a contract. For them to work, you have to put faith in them, for better or for worse.
This has been used by many people in Japan. Besides, everything in the world has value to everybody if you take the time to appreciate it.
Well, I'm finished. Now, I'll have to check how the results apply in the book.
Where's your book?
Back in my room, but that will only take a second...
*ALARM*
Come on, Kanchou. It's time to fight!
Wait! Weren't you going to check on your fortune for the battle?
There's no time for that! When push comes to shove, the future may come as it wills, but the warriors strikes regardless.
@BATTLE
I hope this works...
Hey there, Hiei. How's it going?
Good! We picked up a variety of seafood recently – even sea cucumbers – so I decided to cook some food for everyone.
Great! What's on the menu?
With a little luck, Shandong style. Otherwise, I'll see.
Ah, so you're having some trouble with it, then.
Well, I have not actually made food in this style before, but I heard people raving about it when we besieged Tsingtao.
You never got the chance to try it yourself, though?
No, we were pulled out before the siege ended. Although, this food is not for me, remember?
You said you were going to share it with people, but surely there will be enough for you to get some yourself.
You are forgetting that I eat solely for fuel, and I was recently restocked. Better if someone else can take it and enjoy it more.

Fields.MenuText: Even so, you picked this specific type of food, so you clearly must have some interest in it.
In that case, why don't I share my portion with you?
It's okay to enjoy the fruits of your labor, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right, I just feel guilty, when my other comrades that day also did not have the chance.
No, I couldn't –
I did not think of it like that, but you have a point. I take satisfaction in simply doing my job, but I suppose experiencing the results helps connect me more to the work.
All right. I can enjoy a few bites before resuming my meditation. Assuming that I finish the meal, that is.
Don't worry. You're doing great.
*ALARM*
The food can wait. I may not be the best cook, but I am above average in sizzling and dicing Funayūrei.
@BATTLE
I'm sure they wouldn't think less of you if they knew. They'd be happy that you are doing well now.
That's not exactly what I meant, but I'm glad you're happy.
Now, now, you recall that it is rude to refuse a gift of hospitality, remember?
Ah, tricky, tricky.
Taking up sewing?
Not particularly. I just wanted to make a flag to guide us to victory in the coming trials.
That's good. Though an image of plants isn't exactly a fighting symbol. You certainly have a green thumb.
Show respect to that emblem! It is the very heraldry of the Toyotomi clan – and Hideyoshi himself!
Wasn't he one of the big figures in unifying Japan?
That he was. He came from humble origins but became one of Nobunaga's finest soldiers, and in time continued his legacy.
But didn't they burn down your mountain?
They burned down the temple; the mountain endured. Besides, Hideyoshi later gave support to rebuilding the temple, so I owe him much gratitude.
I see. You seem to really respect him.
I certainly do. He even organized a plan to absorb Korea into our sphere of influence, did you know? A shame it took much longer than he anticipated.

Fields.MenuText: Well, whether it represents Hideyoshi, or your own love for the earth, I think it suits you perfectly.
If I recall correctly, he let the power really get to his head later on in life.
Given how the first invasion was a disaster, I'm not sure he was the best leader.

Fields.DialogueText: Arigatō, Kanchou. I will do my best to prove myself worthy of such an honor.
Such is the corruptive nature of this world. I only hope that I can prevent myself from falling to the same delusion as I grow stronger.
How dare you insult one of our finest leaders! Though it is a sin when the costs of war fail to bring greater harmony in the end.
Well, I'll let you get back to making it.
Don't worry, I'm almost done.
*ALARM*
And looks like now is a good time to use it.
For Japan! For the Co-Prosperity Sphere!
@BATTLE
Are you okay? You seem kind of frustrated.
Perhaps, but I can hardly complain. That is life.
But what's troubling you?
Oh, I was trying to write a letter like you were suggesting, but I am having some trouble getting started.
Writer's block, eh? Happens to all of us.
Still, it makes me wonder if this was the best endeavor. I hardly wish to upset them with a faulty note. Wars have been started over such things.
I think you're exaggerating a bit, Hiei.
Well, could you help me? Please?

Fields.MenuText: Try making it a poem.
Write what you know.
Speak from the heart.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds good. Haiku and other forms of poetry have been the avenue of courtly communications for centuries.
You mean, like writing about battle techniques and meditation?
That is a difficult task. Yet one that I welcome. If we cannot explain the feelings in our souls, how can any of us reach enlightenment?
Well, I'd better get to writing while my brain is bursting with ideas. Arigatō, Kanchou.
You're welcome. I'm sure whoever you're writing it to will be very happy.
I hope so. If not, it would be a disgrace to His Excellency.
His Excellency...?
*ALARM*
Perhaps I can also write about our coming victory – but first things first.
@BATTLE
If it's what you can talk about easily, sure. I just hope they find it interesting.
Ready for your next battle lesson, Kanchou?
Ready whenever you are, Teacher.
Good. But steel yourself. The next lesson will be especially hard. Actually... do you want to back out now? I won't hold it against you.
After we've come so far? No way!
We'll see if you keep that attitude. This time, I don't want you to even try to defend yourself. Instead, concentrate entirely on attacking me.
Huh? Isn't that kind of dangerous?
It is, but it's something you have to overcome for battles. After all, a ship won't be able to dodge attacks that easily. You have to weather the blows and close in.
And you think that I am up for that?
I believe that you have the potential to break past your current limits.
"Break" is one way to put it, I guess.
But it is ultimately up to you. What is your choice?

Fields.MenuText: If I don't try now, will I ever be able to?
I'm scared. I'm not like you... I'm only human.
I'm ready for this.

Fields.DialogueText: A question worth asking yourself, Kanchou.
Which makes it all the more commendable for getting this far.
There is the heart of a dragon, determined to win!
I'll do it.
Very well, but take care. I will try to hold back, but it will still be brutal.
Here I come! Give me everything you've got!
Kanchou! Are you okay?
Fine, Hiei. I really got you, didn't I?
You did, didn't you?
*ALARM*
Take it easy, Kanchou. I'll handle things while you rest.
@BATTLE
OOF!
Hello, Hiei. I see you've got a letter there.
I sure do!
Got a reply from one of your correspondences, then?
Yes, and I was pleasantly surprised. I had been wondering if he would actually open it himself, but then he even wrote a return reply.
That's great! Who's it from?
Someone I worked with in a prior tour.
Come on, that could be almost anybody. Who?
Promise you won't tell.
Okay, I won't. Why are you so nervous?
It is from Prince Takamatsu.
That's right, you said you met him before. And he actually responded?
And that is why I want you to keep this between us.
Why? I think this is a great honor.
That's the point. Having such informal relations with a Kami would be a scandal if the word spread.

Fields.MenuText: I suspect that it is also because you are embarrassed with yourself.
I'm just happy that you are building a bond with him and others.
It won't stay a secret forever, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: You've reached the crux of my worries, as to be expected from you. Yes, I just wonder, why me?
Arigatō. I... hope I can make this connection blossom, somehow.
I acknowledge that, but... at least this can limit the risk for a time.
Okay, I won't tell unless you want me to. But I'll be here to support you in this.
Arigatō, Kanchou.
*ALARM*
Looks like we have company! Hiei, get ready!
@BATTLE
Why not you?
Nice job with the landscaping, Hiei. Those trees and pools look really natural. Is the water supposed to swirl like that, though?
Actually, they are. I based them off the Naruto whirlpools.
You know, I'm a little wary about having things like this on board. They're definitely not something I'd like to swim or sail into, that's for sure.
I admit that natural features can often be dangerous, but they are also majestic in their own way. My own artificial replications are but poor imitations.
Out of curiosity, what got you so interested in the outdoors? I know you talk a lot about your mountain, but you haven't even seen it yourself.
No, but I have had the chance in my second – no, third – home.
What do you mean?
I have been stationed off and on at the Kure naval headquarters, and I had the opportunities to see parts of Setonaikai National Park.
Whoa, that's pretty cool. I have a feeling that you must have really liked it.
I did. I may have been born in the sea, but I think the greatest beauty is seeing how life emerges from the void, whether islands from the water or flowers on a mountaintop.
That's a pretty interesting perspective you have.
Arigatō. I just wonder if I will ever be able to truly experience them. To walk on mountains and climb trees...

Fields.MenuText: Hey, you're a strong warrior, aren't you? I'm sure you'll find a way someday.
Take comfort in the things you can experience and enjoy in the present.
I guess it's a matter of faith.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I vow that I will not fall in battle until I set foot on my homeland's soil and kiss my mountain.
Excellent point. To yearn for things not yet in our reach is human, but we cannot let it prevent us from appreciating our lives as they are.
Indeed, that is the case. I will continue to pray to the kami and Buddhas for a miracle that will surely happen one day.
Anyway, we're getting off the topic. You can keep the whirlpools, but please put some rails along them. I don't want anyone to fall in and drown.
Understood, Kanchou.
Huh, they're really foaming now, for some reason.
I think I know why. Up ahead!
@BATTLE
I think I've got it now.
Got what, exactly?
I am attempting the art of oshibana, flower pressing.
I see. What made you interested in it?
Well, I thought that this was a way to make sure that the dying flowers wouldn't go to waste when their time came.
That makes sense. It's good to recycle things like that. But what are you going to use them for?
I want to include some of them in another letter I'm writing.
You mean Nobu –
Not so loud!
Sorry. But are you?
Yes, but I am unsure which flower I should use. Do you have any suggestions?

Fields.MenuText: How about a chrysanthemum?
You should send him a cherry blossom.
A water lily would work pretty well.

Fields.DialogueText: The imperial symbol? He surely has better ones at his disposal. Then again, it would be what he deserves with his rank.
That would work well. A cherry blossom is a lovely, passionate display of nature's vitality.
You're right. It would fit me very well, as a flower on the sea. I hope that it will remind him of me...
Arigatō, Kanchou. I always appreciate your help.
You're welcome. You two must be getting pretty close, if you're sending flowers...
What of it?!
Nothing, I was just joking. What's wrong?
*ALARM*
Time to press and flatten some Funayūrei with our artillery.
@BATTLE
Nice postcard. Where is it from?
Port Arthur. Kongou and I made a stop there for a few months back in the day.
That's interesting. What was your favorite part of the city?
Lots of things. But my favorite by far was the opportunity to pay homage to the Kanto Shrine. It is an imperial shrine of the first rank, so I felt honored to attend to it.
Kanto? But I thought Port Arthur was in China!
It is. But we established the shrine there after we took over. It represents our vision of uniting China, and all of Asia, under the wise guidance of our Emperor.
I'm not sure the locals would agree on that point.
That is understandable. In the west, there is a parable about men being blind in a cave. So we must bring them into the light of the sun, no matter if they refuse to see reason.

Fields.MenuText: Sometimes people need to be able to find the path on their own. Isn't that the way to true enlightenment?
If it is the right way, true. But how can you be so sure that you're right and they're wrong?
Does that justify oppressing their own way of life, though?

Fields.DialogueText: It is. Perhaps this will simply make them resentful. Why can't they just voluntarily embrace their destiny?
That is a dark thing to imply about our vision, Kanchou... especially since you may be right. There are many ways through life, and who is to say which is wrong or right?
Conflict is a necessary part of life for change to occur. Sometimes you have to burn a forest for new things to grow. But... I don't know.
Maybe the shrine's location isn't the best. But I was really happy to see it, since it helped me feel connected to the imperial family and to Japan as a whole.
Well, maybe you can visit a key shrine on the main islands when we're through with the war.
That sounds great. But let us focus on the present challenges first.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I was wondering if you could give me some advice, please.
Of course, Hiei. What seems to be troubling you?
I have been thinking. I want to start a school, of sorts, for both meditation and warfare.
Sort of like what we've been doing together? That makes sense, but I don't see where the problem is with all that.
There's no issue with that stage of the plan, though I may want your help as a co-instructor once you pass the last tests. But I want to go further.
What do you mean by that?
I want to found an international school, with imperial sanction, on the shores of Japan. Then I can help people of all sorts find strength and enlightenment.
That sounds great, but you're still not explaining the challenge. Unless if it's that you're nervous about the whole thing.
That is exactly it. I'm unsure if I can make this work, and failure to properly teach would dishonor my ancestors and home.

Fields.MenuText: You're the best choice there is to represent Japan on the matter.
Better to try and fail than never to try at all.
Believe in yourself. This is what your dream is, right?

Fields.DialogueText: I disagree with that – there are others with better qualifications – but you have a point. Given how the press seems to be focusing on me, I should set a good example.
I agree, to hesitate in cowardice is the mark of a lesser man. So I will attempt the challenge. But I will never allow myself to fail, no matter what.
It is. I don't want to be too full of myself, but perhaps I should start putting faith in my capabilities to a higher degree.
Arigatō, Kanchou. This talk has made me feel better about the whole thing.
Don't mention it. In any case, that explains why you've been so busy with the correspondence with the prince.
No, my relationship with him is of an entirely different matter.
What do you...?
*ALARM*
Will you look at that? Time for our next live-fire training exercise, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
"Though we have not met / Our memories connect us / 'Til we meet again." No, no... that's not quite right.
What are you working on?
Yipe! Kanchou, good to see you!
Good to see you too, I hope. Are you okay? Though I have to admit, it was kind of funny to see you squeak like that. You look kind of cute with your face all red.
Kanchou!
Don't worry, I'm only teasing. But seriously, what are you working on?
It's a secret. But... I could use your help. It's another letter to Takamatsu.
I see. So you're going for poetry in this one, I take it. Well, poems are pretty diverse, so I'm sure you will find one that works.
No. It has to be perfect, given the message I'm trying to send across.
And what sort of message is that?
... A confession of love.
Really?
He is a really fascinating person, and I've come to enjoy our correspondences. But I'm afraid of what he will think of such a thing – especially if I mess this up!

Fields.MenuText: Be up front about it.
Focus on a scene that has value to both of you.
Just speak in your own voice.

Fields.DialogueText: True, such is the way of a warrior. Actions are what count.
Like the time he gazed at the moon from my stern at Sasebo? Perfect.
That is all I can do in the end. Speak, and hope I can hear his own voice in return.
Anyway, you won't know until you try. If things work out, you have my whole-hearted support.
Arigatō... Arigatō, Kanchou. You are a good friend to me.
You're welcome. And good luck.
*ALARM*
Time for another round, eh? Let's move out, Hiei.
For the Imperial Line! For our camaraderie! And for my Kanchou!
@BATTLE
